a {wi}child{/wi} of nature

barbed wire … is truly a {wi}child{/wi} of the plains

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}cild{/it}; akin to Goth {it}kilthei{/it} womb, and perhaps to Sanskrit {it}jaṭhara{/it} belly

a person not yet of the age of majority

dt: {bc}an uncommon, sometimes life-threatening, inflammatory condition that chiefly affects children and adolescents and usually develops two to four weeks following infection with or exposure to the coronavirus causing {d_link|COVID-19|COVID-19}

The typical symptoms of multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children are fever, abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, skin rash, fatigue, headache, conjunctivitis, hypotension, and redness or swelling of the hands, feet, tongue or lips. Severe complications may include cardiac dysfunction, myocarditis, coronary artery dilatation or aneurysm, acute kidney damage, or shock.

dt.t: Children's National Hospital is treating 23 children for an inflammatory syndrome associated with covid-19, a hospital spokesperson said Wednesday night. The illness, known as {wi}multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children{/wi}, is a recently discovered complication from the novel coronavirus.

aq.auth: Fenit Nirappil and Ann E. Marimow

dt.t: The syndrome bears a resemblance to {d_link|Kawasaki disease|Kawasaki disease}, another rare inflammatory syndrome that occurs in young children. But {wi}multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children{/wi} has been reported to occur in children older than this.

The medical condition, known as {wi}multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children{/wi}, or MIS-C, is a rare but potentially deadly medical condition typically affecting multiple organs—including the heart, kidneys, brain, among others—that has been detected in children or young adults up to 21 years of age who are believed to have had COVID-19 or been exposed to it, according to the federal Centers for Disease Control.

One rare but serious complication children can develop from a coronavirus infection is known as {wi}multisystem inflammatory syndrome{/wi}, or MIS-C, and at least 570 cases have been reported, the CDC said. As the pandemic continues, health care providers should be on the lookout for the syndrome that most commonly causes abdominal pain, vomiting and a skin rash.

shortdef: an uncommon, sometimes life-threatening, inflammatory condition that chiefly affects children and adolescents and usually develops two to four weeks following infection with or exposure to the coronavirus causing COVID-19 —abbreviation MIS-C—called also pediatric multisystem inflammatory syndrome, PMIS

dt: {bc}a child whose parents were not married when the child was conceived

dt.t: My older sister, Jean Marie, was the {wi}love child{/wi} of an affair my mother had with a married man who, instead of leaving his wife for my mother, died of a heart attack.
A pair of furry Ugg slides that are basically a {wi}love child{/wi} of your comfiest slippers and practical summer sandals.

dt: {bc}something (such as a project or collaboration) that is a product of hard work and devotion

dt.t: The museum is the {wi}love child{/wi} of the company's owner, Jacques Lorch, who for twenty-five years has been ferreting out artifacts pertaining to the subject that is his passion.

shortdef: a child whose parents were not married when the child was conceived; especially : the child of an affair — often used figuratively
something (such as a project or collaboration) that is a product of hard work and devotion

dt.t: … it came to her what a glory it would be to be the mother of a {wi}man-child{/wi} like this.

dt: {bc}a man who has the qualities of a child {bc}a childlike man

dt.t: … a largely likable tale about a 38-year-old {wi}man-child{/wi} trying finally to grow up.

shortdef: a man who has the qualities of a child : a childlike man
